user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtTest_AddCommon:
```c
void UtTest_AddCommon(void (*Test)(void), void (*Setup)(void), void (*Teardown)(void), const char *TestName,
                      uint32 EntryType)
{
    UtTestDataBaseEntry_t UtTestDataBaseEntry;

    memset(&UtTestDataBaseEntry, 0, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry));
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Test     = Test;
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Setup    = Setup;
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Teardown = Teardown;
    if (TestName != NULL)
    {
        strncpy(UtTestDataBaseEntry.TestName, TestName, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry.TestName) - 1);
    }

    UT_BSP_Lock();
    UtList_Add(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr, &UtTestDataBaseEntry, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry_t), EntryType);
    UT_BSP_Unlock();
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtTest_AddCommon:
void UtList_Add(UtListHead_t *ListHead, void *Data, uint32 DataSize, uint32 Tag)
{
    UtListNode_t *TagHead;
    UtListNode_t *NewNode;

    TagHead = UtList_GetHead(ListHead, Tag);
    if (TagHead != NULL)
    {
        NewNode      = UtList_NewNode(Data, DataSize);
        NewNode->Tag = Tag;
        UtList_Insert_Before(TagHead, NewNode);
    }
}
...
UtListNode_t *UtList_GetHead(UtListHead_t *ListHead, uint32 Tag)
{
    if (Tag >= ListHead->NumberOfTags)
    {
        return NULL;
    }
    return &ListHead->Tags[Tag];
}
...
UtListNode_t *UtList_NewNode(void *Data, uint32 DataSize)
{
    union NodeAllocator
    {
        UtListNode_t Node;
        double       AlignDbl;
        void *       AlignPtr;
        long         AlignLong;
    } * AllocNode;

    AllocNode = malloc(sizeof(union NodeAllocator) + DataSize);
    memset(AllocNode, 0, sizeof(union NodeAllocator));
    AllocNode->Node.Data     = &AllocNode[1];
    AllocNode->Node.DataSize = DataSize;
    memcpy(AllocNode->Node.Data, Data, DataSize);

    AllocNode->Node.Next = &AllocNode->Node;
    AllocNode->Node.Prev = &AllocNode->Node;

    return &AllocNode->Node;
}
...
void UtList_Insert_Before(UtListNode_t *ExistingNode, UtListNode_t *NewNode)
{
    NewNode->Next       = ExistingNode;
    NewNode->Prev       = ExistingNode->Prev;
    NewNode->Prev->Next = NewNode;
    NewNode->Next->Prev = NewNode;
}
...
typedef struct
{
    void (*Test)(void);
    void (*Setup)(void);
    void (*Teardown)(void);

    /* Note - the name entry should be long enough to support a GroupName.TestName pattern,
     * hence why it uses double the OS_MAX_API_NAME length */
    char TestName[OS_MAX_API_NAME * 2];
} UtTestDataBaseEntry_t
...
UtAssert_Global_t UtAssert_Global
...
void UT_BSP_Lock(void)
{
    OS_BSP_Lock_Impl();
}
...
void UT_BSP_Unlock(void)
{
    OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl();
}
...
void OS_BSP_Lock_Impl(void)
{
    int status;

    status = pthread_mutex_lock(&OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutex_lock: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * Temporarily Disable/Defer thread cancellation.
         * Note that OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl() calls write() which is a cancellation point.
         * So if this calling task is canceled, it risks leaving the BSP locked.
         */
        pthread_setcancelstate(PTHREAD_CANCEL_DISABLE, &OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessCancelState);
    }
}
...
void OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl(void)
{
    int status;

    status = pthread_mutex_unlock(&OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutex_unlock: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
    else
    {
        /* Restore previous cancellability state */
        pthread_setcancelstate(OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessCancelState, NULL);
    }
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I inspected all provided code fragments (UtTest_AddCommon, UtList_Add, UtList_GetHead, UtList_NewNode, UtList_Insert_Before, the UtTestDataBaseEntry_t definition, UtAssert_Global usage, UT_BSP_Lock/Unlock wrappers, and OS_BSP_Lock_Impl/OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl). None of these fragments call the standard library function memcmp. Details:

- UtTest_AddCommon: uses memset and strncpy to initialize and copy the TestName; strncpy is a copy function, not a comparison. No memcmp present.
- UtList_Add / UtList_GetHead / UtList_NewNode / UtList_Insert_Before: use pointer checks, integer comparisons (Tag >= NumberOfTags), malloc, memset, memcpy and pointer manipulation to build list nodes. memcpy and memset are data movement/initialization functions, not comparisons. No memcmp present.
- UtTestDataBaseEntry_t: just a struct definition with a char array for TestName; declaration only, no use of memcmp.
- UT_BSP_Lock / UT_BSP_Unlock and OS_BSP_* implementations: use pthread_mutex_lock/unlock, pthread_setcancelstate, strerror for diagnostics. These are synchronization and error-reporting operations, not string comparisons and do not call memcmp.

Because the rule prohibits using memcmp to compare null-terminated strings, the only relevant check is presence of memcmp calls that take C strings. No memcmp calls appear in the provided code. Therefore there are no suspicious fragments to investigate with respect to MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 in the supplied code. If other source files exist, they would need to be checked separately for any memcmp usage on null-terminated strings.
